channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Keith Bradsher Answers Readers’ Questions on the Philippines
item.description: Mr. Bradsher, a Times reporter covering the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan, answered readers’ questions about doing his job under difficult conditions and the relief efforts underway.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Joaquín Hernández Galicia, Leader of Powerful Mexican Union, Dies at 91
item.description: Mr. Hernández Galicia led a union of 200,000 workers employed by Mexico’s huge state-owned oil company, Pemex, and they revered him for the generous benefits he won for them.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Joaquín Hernández Galicia and his union were widely viewed as corrupt.

item.title: Relief Supplies Pour Into Philippines, but Remote Areas Still Suffer
item.description: While hard-hit urban areas are finally getting adequate supplies, the region’s rural hinterland has been largely left to fend for itself in the week since Typhoon Haiyan hit.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in Guiuan, on Samar Island.

item.title: Growing Clamor About Inequities of Climate Crisis
item.description: The debate over how to address the disproportionate effects of climate change on poorer countries has gained momentum, but the steps can be politically daunting.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: People evacuating after a storm hit the Puntland region of Somalia.

item.title: A Russian GPS Using U.S. Soil Stirs Spy Fears
item.description: American spy agencies fear that allowing monitor stations in the United States for Russia’s version of GPS could compromise United States intelligence.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A technician from Russia's space agency at a monitor station that opened in Brazil.

item.title: Runoff Vote Is Completed in Maldives
item.description: The half brother of a former leader of the island nation appears to have been elected president, ending a tumultuous process.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Chess: Challenger Takes Lead Over World Chess Champion
item.description: Magnus Carlsen won his second straight game over Viswanathan Anand. He now leads 4 points to 2, with 6.5 points needed to clinch the title.
item.dc:creator: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: New Syrian Refugees Descend on Lebanon
item.description: Refugees poured into Arsal, Lebanon, amid reports that a battle was beginning along the Syrian border.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Success of Chinese Leader’s Ambitious Economic Plan May Rest on Rural Regions
item.description: The success of an economic overhaul could hinge on policy battles over land, money and a fiscal system that has bred public discontent and financial hazards.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Justin Jin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hobbyists flew kites in farmland cleared for development in Chengdu, China. Land issues may present a hurdle for reform.

item.title: Syrian Government’s Forces Gain, but a Siege War Goes On
item.description: The Assad government has made gains, and the momentum has tipped, however slightly, in its direction even while the nation remains badly fractured.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Smoke from shelling, reportedly by government forces, in Aleppo on Thursday.

item.title: Russian Manhunt Ends as Bus Bomber’s Husband Is Killed
item.description: Officials said Dmitri Sokolov, 21, admitted during a prolonged standoff that he had made the explosive belt that was detonated last month in Volgograd.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Defection of Longtime Ally Splits Center-Right in Italy
item.description: The rupture within the movement of Silvio Berlusconi was led by his longtime protégé, who announced he would refuse to join Mr. Berlusconi’s rebranded party.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Deadly Kabul Bombing Sends Message on Security Pact Vote
item.description: At least 10 people were killed as a bomb exploded near a university where elders are scheduled to vote on a security agreement with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghan policemen worked at the scene of a suicide bombing on Saturday in Kabul.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: To a Philosopher-General in Israel, Peace Is the Time to Prepare for War
item.description: The departing commander of Israel’s Army in northern Galilee, Brig. Gen. Herzl Halevi, is convinced that Israel will go to war again with Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The interesting issue is how you create a longer gap between the wars,” said Brig. Gen. Herzl Halevi.

item.title: In Worst-Hit Area of Tacloban, a Killer From Two Sides
item.description: Barangay 88, which sits on a peninsula and is one of Tacloban’s most populous neighborhoods, endured massive destruction by last week’s typhoon in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan in Guiuan, on Samar Island.

item.title: Out of Europe’s Jobs Crisis, Voices of the Young
item.description: The New York Times asked young people in Europe to share their stories about how the crisis has affected their lives. Here is a selection of the responses.

item.title: Japan Backs Off From Emissions Targets, Citing Fukushima Disaster
item.description: Tokyo’s decision to no longer adhere to its plan could complicate efforts to forge a global climate change pact.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 4 Said to Recruit for Syrian War
item.description: Authorities have arrested four men suspected of involvement in a network sending fighters to Syria to join radical Sunni Islamist groups, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Libya: U.S. Offers Rewards in Benghazi
item.description: The State Department said it had been quietly offering rewards of up to $10 million for information about last year’s attack on an American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Toronto Council Curbs Mayor
item.description: A special session of the Toronto City Council removed Mayor Rob Ford’s power to appoint some city officials, after he admitted using crack cocaine and binge drinking.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: 69 Political Prisoners Freed
item.description: The move came as part of a promise by Myanmar’s president to free all such detainees by the end of the year.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Boat Accident Kills 12 Migrants
item.description: Twelve migrants, believed to be Syrians, were found dead after a plastic boat still tied to rocks capsized in calm weather, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 7 Killed in Sectarian Clash
item.description: Shiites traveling in a religious procession near Pakistan’s capital killed seven Sunnis from an Islamic seminary for insulting them as they passed, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Arrests Begin in Vote-Fraud Case
item.description: The federal police began arresting a dozen powerful political figures, bankers and businessmen convicted in a vast vote-buying scandal that surfaced more than eight years ago.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: African Call to Delay Kenyans’ Trials Fails at U.N.
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s charges of crimes against humanity has led to tension with the African Union.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
